reviewText:
Holopoint is an interesting VR experience. The arena you play in is cool, and the core gameplay itself is interesting but the overall experience was hindered by a few major flaws.

First, the archery. It doesn't feel right. There is a sweet spot for nocking arrows into the bow, and it can be hard to find. Many people I've shown this game to took several minutes to figure out how to just prep the arrow to fire it. Another problem is that the aiming for the bow is done with the hand that holds the bow, not with a combined mixture of both hands. This made almost all of my shots miss until I figured that out. As a game that completely focuses on archery combat, these problems really hurt it.

Second is the enemies. The game is advertised as fighting 'responsive targets, samurai, and highly dangerous ninjas', and so far all I've fought is cubes. I'm almost 10/30 (?) waves in. Repeatedly firing arrows at cubes that shoot back when you hit them gets boring and repetitive. Not the best way to start off a game.

This game is only 7$, so its hard to go wrong, but I'm not that interested in playing it again if I have to fight boxes with wonky bow controls. If these two problems got fixed, I wouldn't mind giving it another go.

As a bonus, I credit Holopoint for honing my sense of where my headset cable is at all times.

If the developer would add more scenes, enemies, waves, etc., I'd be very happy. That said, it's still a fine value as it is.

Make sure to check out the settings menu first, because you can adjust how aiming and arrow gripping work. Once you have it right this game will make you feel like Hawkeye and Neo had a baby and that baby is you.

Simple premise, simple graphics, super-fun. If you've ever wanted to live the fantasy of training in a LASER DOJO, honing your archery skills against waves of holographic enemies while dodging & weaving around their attacks like a frickin' ninja, you will have a blast. If you've never had that fantasy...well, you will.

This was more than I expected, and in a good way. Firt off, it actually made me take a break to catch my breath. Did not believe I would have to do that in VR, but this thing did it. Secondly, its actually a rather good challenge. Turning around, making sure you wont get hit, taking down targets - its kind of addicting.

Fantastic game, one of the most engaging I've played. It starts off quite mild, but soon ramps up the number and position of the targets - I was spinning, squatting, weaving around and built up a fine sweat by the end.

Gret concept, very simple and rewarding.  Could stand to have  numbers that come up from the targets to give you better feedback on how the scoring works.  Also, the arrow orientation on the offhand is VERY different than The Lab or Bowslinger, at first very offputting but you get used to it.\n\nI eventually found myself shooting in a japanese longbow style, where I'd hold my offhand up above and shoot down, instead of trying to look down the arrow -- speed over accuracy seems to be key.  Worked up a sweat quickly while playing, good workout game for sure!

After awhile in 'The Lab - Longbow' I end up seeking for something more with archery. I can say Holopoint is a perfect archery VR game to start off with. Especially with that price, you couldn't ask for more!

When I first started out, I had expected the standing targets would simply vanish. They don't. Each standing target will fire back at you once killed. When I progressed further I experienced new targets. Moving toward me to slice my head. Encountered a rare few targets that threw shirukens at me in incredible speed.

The boss battle is exciting to keep you moving and dodging around her shots and have to aim carefully to her weakpoint.

Pro:
-Beginning waves give you good understanding of game mechanics.
-Sharpens reflexes, reaction speed, awareness (highly recommend headphones)
-Mid to High waves will keep you under pressure of overwhelming targets
-Rewards your slight of hand and streak kills (without missing) with fire arrows
-Option to start differnet waves by 5. (Max option is the 25th Wave)
-Lot of replayabilty
-Global Leaderboard to push yourself further

Cons:
Warning for players that love to move around:
-I have smacked my controllers together a few times. Under pressure of massive targets.
-Hit my VR twice to pull my arrows quickly from my quiver.
-After awhile, realize targets have specific spawns in each wave
-Some panic / spook moments of target right next to you when you turn.
-Can't really hear each footsteps distance, only the floors creak and armor rattling.
-Don't play too long or else feel the sweat on your VR sweatpads for an hour to dry up.

Holopoint gets me excited for a number of reasons, the least of which is how freaking amazing the game itself is. Don't get me wrong, I think this is one of the best bang-for-your-buck experiences in the early days of the Vive. If I tried this thing in an arcade one afternoon, I'd be spending well over seven bucks to play it as much as I have (and intend to going forward).\n\nWhat REALLY gets me excited is thinking about where developers are going to take this concept, and how far they intend to run with it. A bit more variety in environments, enemies and control style (as well as some polish on how to work the bow) would make a game like this a truly killer app for the Vive. Even in its current state, I would call it a top 5 release title from what is becoming a quite sizable early batch of VR titles.
An incredibly fun workout, slightly frustrating controls but you can look past it, For the price this is absolutely worth it. Hope the dev keeps improving/expanding!

Of all the Virtual Reality games I have in my library, this is hands down the favorite of most of the people I know, myself included. The controls are very intuitive... boiling down to simply knocking the arrow with the trigger, drawing, and releasing the arrow by releasing the trigger. Move in room-scale to dip, duck, and lean to avoid enemy fire. The intensity of this game is currently unmatched! You will break a sweat. You will love every second of it. Holopoint is played at the start and end of every VR session. Often times my friends will stop playing a game, after having exhausted it, and come back to holopoint again and again.

Gameplay Breakdown:
You are in a dojo and your room-scale play area is a mat. You can not leave the matt. Enemies will spawn in 360 degrees around you. You must shoot them with your bow while dodging their counter-fire by dipping, ducking, and moving about your play area. Very simple control scheme and solid bowplay.

Pros:
+Most solid archery I have played yet.
+Hitboxes are perfect.
+Nonstop balls to the wall action with a very pleasing difficulty curve.
+It's so intuitive you're garunteed to understand it immediately.
+Immense replayability.

Cons:
-I can't really think of anything? Is being too intense a con? It's not a relaxing game. If you have a sports injury or are otherwise disabled this title is probably not for you.
-I get tired and can't play this game all day.

You starting with shooting at cubes... Sounds boring right? Not as simple as it sounds. The moment you hit one, it retaliates and shoots back as they shatter. And if you leave them around for too long... they also shoot. This goes on with every increasing amounts and eventually you simply cannot hit them all before one shoots without you hitting it first... and thats when things change radically and new types of enemies start relentlessly be thrown, a suprise after another. And no, there are no shields, so no turtleing, and you have to dodge all the projectiles.

Thats when things get really interesting and accuracy becomes very important.

And its not just Point and shoot, you have to use both your hands to align your shots at your target, and coordinate with the other to reach the quever. You will feel even more bad *** when you manage to hit multiple targets in a row.

I highly recommend this to anyone that the space to go side to side in, and has the physical fitness to play it: but do pull off some practise on turning with the head set on. What is Holopoint?
Holopoint is a HTC Vive VR game where you shoot blue cubes with a bow and arrow. Seems simple untill they start shooting back. The idea is that you have eyes in the back of yor head so you can both eliminate cubes for points and avoid cubes shooting at you. When a cube dies it more often than not shoots you, when a cube turns orange it shoots you. How do you avoud these shots? You dodge, duck, dip, dive and dodge your way around them. Also there is samurai and ninjas.

Is Holopoint good?
Holopoint has amassed an impressive 97% positive feedback and with good reason, it is simple but fun. You need no archery skill and it works well even in a relatively small space and for a measly £5 pricetag it is tempting to say no to.
For how cheap the game is and for how much fun and exercise you and some friends can get I think that Holopoint is very much worth it
